questions.text: Patient comes with crush injury to upper limb, doctor is concerned about gangrene and sepsis. What can help decide between amputation and limb salvage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) MESS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. GCS score. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to objectively describe the extent of impaired consciousness in all acute medical and trauma patients. The scale assesses patients according to three aspects of responsiveness : eye-opening, motor, and verbal responses. Reporting each of these separately provides a clear, communicable picture of a patient’s state. The score expression is the sum of the scores as well as the individual elements. For example, a score of 10 might be expressed as GCS10 = E3V4M3. The Glasgow Coma Scale divides into three parameters : best eye response (E), best verbal response (V) and best motor response (M). The levels of response are ‘scored’ from 1, for no response , up to normal values of 4 (Eye-opening response), 5 (Verbal response) and 6 (Motor response) . The total Score has values between 3 and 15 ; 3 being the worst and 15 being the highest.
  • • Option B. GCS score.
  • • impaired consciousness
  • • three aspects of responsiveness
  • • three parameters
  • • 1, for no response
  • • 4 (Eye-opening response), 5 (Verbal response) and 6 (Motor response)
  • • total Score
  • • 3 and 15
  • • Option C. Gustilo-Anderson classification. The purpose of the Gustilo-Anderson classification is to provide a prognostic framework that guides treatment for open (or compound) fractures , with higher grade injuries associated with higher risk of complications.
  • • Option C. Gustilo-Anderson classification.
  • • open (or compound) fractures
  • • Option D. ASIA guidelines. The American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) Impairment Scale is a standardized neurological examination used by the rehabilitation team to assess the sensory and motor levels affected by the spinal cord injury . The scale has five classification levels, ranging from complete loss of neural function in the affected area to completely normal. The results to set functional goals based on the neurological level of injury.
  • • Option D. ASIA guidelines.
  • • American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) Impairment Scale
  • • neurological examination
  • • assess the sensory and motor levels affected by the spinal cord injury
  • • five classification
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • To decide between amputation and limb salvage, MESS scoring system is used. Higher the score, higher the chances of amputation.
  • • To decide between amputation and limb salvage, MESS scoring system is used. Higher the score, higher the chances of amputation.

The clinical examination of a knee is addressed to evaluate three aspects: 1) patello-femoral joint/extensor mechanism; 2) articular (meniscal and chondral) lesions; and 3) knee instability. It is associated with avulsion of AIIS. The patient presents with pain and tenderness on the anterior aspect of the hip and mid-thigh at muscle belly.
  • • Option B. Rectus femoris strain.
  • • Option C. Gluteus medius strain. Gluteus medius strain is uncommon but can occur in sports like running or football. It occurs due to repetitive force on the contracting muscle. The patient experience sudden sharp pain in the buttocks that may reduce over time.
  • • Option C. Gluteus medius strain.
  • • Option D. Hamstring strain. Hamstring strains are caused by a rapid extensive contraction or a violent stretch of the hamstring muscle which causes high mechanical stress. Hamstring strains are common in sports with a dynamic character like sprinting, jumping, contact sports where quick eccentric contractions are regular. In soccer, it is the most frequent injury. It results in a sudden, severe pain in the posterior thigh. Also, a "popping" or tearing sensation is described. Sometimes swelling and ecchymosis are possible.
  • • Option D. Hamstring strain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a H/o Intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pott’s spine . Pott’s spine or tuberculosis of the spine is caused by mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is usually secondary to hematogenous spread from a primary site, commonly lungs. The common site of involvement in the spine is the paradiscal region because the subchondral bone around the disc space is supplied by the paradiscal vessels. This infection leads to progressive vertebral destruction and kyphotic deformity of the spine. The patient typically presents with back pain. Rest pain is rare. Radicular pain can be the presenting symptom. Constitutional symptoms of weight loss and fever are less commonly associated (more common with pulmonary involvement). There can be a cold abscess in the affected region. Nerve compression can be secondary to vertebral body collapse, leading to exaggerated DTRs or sensory loss.
  • • Option A. Pott’s spine
  • • Option B. Multiple myeloma . Multiple myeloma is a neoplastic proliferation of plasma cells affecting multiple organ systems. The patient may present with anemia, fatigue, bone pain that worsens on movement and in the night. The affected vertebra is collapsed or have a compression fracture. Symptoms of weight loss, nausea, muscle weakness and mental confusion may be present along with kidney failure, hypercalcemia.
  • • Option B. Multiple myeloma
  • • Option D. Bone metastasis . In bone metastasis, there is sparing of the intervertebral space. The symptoms of spinal canal invasion and spinal cord compression may be present. Pain is the most common presenting initial symptom in patients. The pain is aching and deep, often occurs at night. Also, if nerve involvement has occurred, the pain is sharp and shooting in a specific dermatomal distribution. When the tumor has extended inside the spinal canal, motor, and sensory weakness may become permanent.
  • • Option D. Bone metastasis
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The provided information about the patient’s symptoms of severe back ache with urinary incontinence with history of intervertebral disc prolapse, without fever or weight loss is suggestive of cauda equina syndrome. Remember, bladder and bowel involvement is typical of cauda equina syndrome, and it is not associated with constitutional symptoms, rather it presents with disc prolapse and cord compression.
  • • The provided information about the patient’s symptoms of severe back ache with urinary incontinence with history of intervertebral disc prolapse, without fever or weight loss is suggestive of cauda equina syndrome.
  • • Remember, bladder and bowel involvement is typical of cauda equina syndrome, and it is not associated with constitutional symptoms, rather it presents with disc prolapse and cord compression.

questions.correct_answer: A. Tuberculosis affection of ulnar bursa
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis affection of ulnar bursa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Pyogenic affection of ulnar bursa. Pyogenic or suppurative flexor tenosynovitis is a severe bacterial infection within the closed space of the digital flexor tendon sheaths. It can cause necrosis of the tendons and devitalization of fingers. It alters the gliding mechanism and creates adhesions within the flexor tendon sheath, resulting in marked loss of finger movements. It can result from bloodstream infection but is generally caused by penetrating finger injuries involving the flexor tendon sheath. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacteria causing this infection. The detection of the 4 Kanavel signs on physical assessment has high sensitivity. A painful passive extension is the earliest sign while flexor sheath tenderness is the last sign to be detected. The presence of erythema, swelling, and tenderness over the thenar eminence in the palm raises the suspicion of the proximal spread of infection to the radial bursa. Patients with an infected ulnar bursa present with pain, swelling, and erythema over the hypothenar eminence.
  • • Option B. Pyogenic affection of ulnar bursa.

questions.text: A patient gives a history of twisting strain and locking of the knee joint. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Avulsion of tibial tubercle. Tibial tubercle fractures are most frequently seen in sports that involve jumping activities. Injury may be caused by quadriceps contraction during knee extension while initiating a jump. Damage can also take place during landing when the quadriceps contracts and the knee flexes to absorb the impact of landing. The patellar ligament inserts on the secondary ossification center, which places the tibial tubercle at risk for an avulsion injury.
  • • Option A. Avulsion of tibial tubercle.
  • • Option C. Tearing of lateral collateral ligament . The most common mechanism of injury is seen via a high-energy blow to the anteromedial knee, combining hyperextension and extreme varus force.
  • • Option C. Tearing of lateral collateral ligament
  • • Option D. Tear of anterior cruciate ligament . A common and frequent injury mechanism is non-contact combined valgus and internal-rotation trauma. Therefore, ACL injuries are often associated with other ligamentous injuries, such as a (partial) rupture of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) or the menisci.
  • • Option D. Tear of anterior cruciate ligament
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The given history of twisting strain and locking of the knee joint is the most common mechanism of injury of meniscal tear.
  • • The given history of twisting strain and locking of the knee joint is the most common mechanism of injury of meniscal tear.

questions.text: True about Cervical spondylosis.

options.label: A
options.text: Most frequently results from an incidence of acute trauma

options.label: B
options.text: Causes compression of nerve roots to produce an upper motor neuron lesion in the lower limbs

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Produces pain and paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the forearm and thumb when affecting the 6th cervical nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Produces pain and paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the forearm and thumb when affecting the 6th cervical nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Most frequently results from an incidence of acute trauma. False. Cervical spondylosis is an age-related degeneration of the intervertebral disc and cervical spinal elements. Degenerative changes in surrounding structures, including the facets joints, posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL), and ligamentum flavum all combine to cause narrowing of the spinal canal and intervertebral foramina. Consequently, the spinal cord, spinal vasculature, and nerve roots can be compressed, resulting in axial neck pain, cervical myelopathy, and cervical radiculopathy.
  • • Option A. Most frequently results from an incidence of acute trauma.
  • • Option B. Causes compression of nerve roots to produce an upper motor neuron lesion in the lower limbs. False. Cervical myelopathy due to spondylotic changes leads to spinal cord compression and consequently upper motor neuron symptoms in the upper limb like spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
  • • Option B. Causes compression of nerve roots to produce an upper motor neuron lesion in the lower limbs.
  • • Option D. Most frequently affects the upper cervical vertebrae. False. Cervical spondylosis involves most commonly the lower cervical vertebrae i.e., C4-C5, C5-C6, C6-C7.
  • • Option D. Most frequently affects the upper cervical vertebrae.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Cervical spondylosis produces pain and paresthesia over the lateral aspect of the forearm and thumb when the 6 th cranial nerve is affected.

questions.text: A patient sustained injury to his knee with a twisting force. On examination, pain is felt more on medial femoral side of knee than tibial side. Injured structure might be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medial collateral ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Anterior cruciate ligament . The most common mechanism of ACL injury is a sudden pivoting or cutting maneuver during sports activity, which is commonly seen in football, basketball, and soccer. The ligament can also tear due to automobile accidents. At the time of the injury, a “pop” or “snap” can sometimes be felt or heard. The amount of pain experienced at the time of the injury is can be severe. Immediate swelling of the knee develops at the time of injury within the first few hours, but the extent of swelling can be limited if the knee is immediately iced or splinted. There is an inability to bear weight on leg along with an instability of the knee.
  • • Option A. Anterior cruciate ligament
  • • Option B. Posterior cruciate ligament . The PCL is usually injured by hyperxtension of the knee while landing after jumping. The PCL can also be injured from a direct blow to the flexed knee, such as falling hard on a bent knee. Most PCL injuries occur with other ligament injuries and severe knee trauma. Often, the knee is dislocated and the nerves and blood vessels are injured. The symptoms of the injury include knee swelling, tenderness in the popliteal fossa, joint instability and pain.
  • • Option B. Posterior cruciate ligament
  • • Option D. Lateral collateral ligament . A lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury is usually caused by pressure or an injury that pushes the knee joint from the inside, which results in stress on the outside part of the joint. The symptoms of a tear in the lateral collateral ligament can include knee swelling, locking or catching of knee with movement, pain or tenderness along the outside of knee, and a feeling of giving way.
  • • Option D. Lateral collateral ligament
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • History of a twisting injury along with pain on the medial side of the knee is suggestive of injury to the medial collateral ligament.
  • • History of a twisting injury along with pain on the medial side of the knee is suggestive of injury to the medial collateral ligament.

questions.text: Sudden inversion of foot leads to rupture of which tendon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior talofibular ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Deltoid ligament . Deltoid Ligament Injury causes pain around medial malleolus. The x-rays appear normal. The ligament has tibial attachment and the other expansions are into talus, navicular, calcaneum, spring ligament. The most common mechanism of injury is supination and external rotation or pronation and external rotation.
  • • Option A. Deltoid ligament
  • • Option C. Posterior talofibular ligament . Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL) injuries are less common than other lateral collateral ligament injuries of the ankle and almost always occur with other injuries. One potential reason for relatively lower PTFL injury rates it is not a major stabilizer of the lateral ankle joint. PTFL injuries have been associated with talar dome ostechondral defect, calcaneofibular ligament (CFL) injury, ATFL injury, and ankle dislocation.
  • • Option C. Posterior talofibular ligament
  • • Posterior talofibular ligament (PTFL) injuries
  • • Option D. Spring ligament . Spring ligament injuries or calcaneonavicular ligament injuries refer to stretching sprains, tears, or ruptures of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament complex and can affect one or more of the three portions. Spring ligament complex injuries are most commonly associated with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction in adult acquired flat foot and are rare in isolation. Middle-aged women are most commonly affected.
  • • Option D. Spring ligament
  • • Spring ligament injuries
  • • calcaneonavicular ligament injuries
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Sudden inversion of the foot leads to rupture of the anterior talofibular ligament, with or without foot plantarflexion.
  • • Sudden inversion of the foot leads to rupture of the anterior talofibular ligament, with or without foot plantarflexion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old professional footballer suffered a twisting injury to his right ankle. On examination, there is a lot of swelling around the medial malleolus but X-ray doesn’t show any fracture. The structure injured could be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Deltoid ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Anterior talofibular ligament. ATFL injuries typically occur with an inversion injury to the ankle, either with or without plantar flexion. The x-ray in ATFL injury may show an avulsion fracture at the fibular end.
  • • Option B. Anterior talofibular ligament.
  • • Option C. Spring ligament . A spring ligament tear can occur because of failure of the tibialis posterior tendon in adult-acquired flatfoot deformity or as an isolated injury with a normal tibialis posterior tendon. Plain radiographs may show flat foot deformity or evidence of hindfoot valgus.
  • • Option C. Spring ligament
  • • Option D. Tendo Achilles . Causes of Achilles tendon rupture include sudden forced plantar flexion of the foot, direct trauma, and long-standing tendinopathy or intratendinous degenerative conditions. Plain radiographs may show soft tissue swelling and obliteration of pre-Achilles fat pad (Kager's triangle).
  • • Option D. Tendo Achilles
  • • Educational objective:

  • • Twisting injury of the ankle with swelling around the medial malleolus and normal x-ray are suggestive deltoid ligament injury.

  • • Option A. Fasciotomy. Needle fasciotomy is an outpatient procedure in which one or more fibrous contractures are sectioned using a blade or the bevel of a needle. Sectioning is achieved by moving the needle in a sawing motion against the fibrous band repeatedly until the band breaks, or until partial sectioning has been achieved and the finger can be extended causing the band to snap. Depending on the severity of the condition some individuals may require more than one session, particularly if there is contracture of the PIP joint. Based on the evidence, the main benefit offered by this procedure is a short-term reduction in the degree of contracture. Recurrence rate is approximately 50% at 3-5 years. Common complications reported in the studies include skin breaks, localized pain and nerve injuries.
  • • Option A. Fasciotomy.

  • • Educational objective:
  • • The best surgical treatment for dupuytren’s contracture is subtotal fasciectomy with skin transplantation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in patella
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in patella

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in tibia . This is known as Osgood-Schlatter Disease . It is a condition where the patellar tendon insertion on the tibial tuberosity is inflamed. It occurs in late childhood, characterized by pain and bony prominence over the tibial tuberosity. The pain is usually exacerbated by physical activities like running, jumping, and climbing stairs. In the acute stage, the margins of the patellar tendon become blurred in radiographs due to the soft tissue swelling. After three to four months, bone fragmentation at the tibial tuberosity is viewed. In the sub-acute stage, soft tissue swelling resolves, but the bony ossicle remains. In the chronic stage, the bone fragment may fuse with the tibial tuberosity which can appear normal. The primary goal in the treatment is the reduction of pain and swelling over the tibial tuberosity. The patient should limit physical activities until the symptoms are resolved.
  • • Option B. Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in tibia
  • • Osgood-Schlatter Disease
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:

  • • Apophysitis of patellar tendon as it inserts in patella is known as Jumper’s knee or patellar tendonitis.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the weak leg straight. This is known as:
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Waddell’s test. It is consists of tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if positive, 0 if negative. Components of test are :
  • • Option A. Waddell’s test.
  • • Components of test are
  • • If 3+ points or more are present, investigate for non-organic cause.
  • • Option B. O’Donoghue’s test. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.
  • • Option B. O’Donoghue’s test.
  • • Option D. McMurray test. It is used to check for meniscus tear. The patient lies supine with the knee flexed. The examiner holds the knee and palpates the joint line with the proximal hand. With the distal hand, the examiner holes the sole of the foot. From the flexed position, the examiner extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and applies a varus stress, then return to maximal flexion and extend the knee with external rotation of tibia and valgus stress. Internal rotation + varus stress tests the lateral meniscus, while external rotation + valgus stress tests the medial meniscus. The test is positive if there is pain, snapping, an audible click or locking.
  • • Option D. McMurray test.

The hemilaminectomy differs from laminectomy surgery in the removal of a very small part of the lamina. The surgery is commonly used to relieve symptoms caused by spinal stenosis and PIVD in the lumbar spine.

questions.text: The most common factor causing Lumbar disc prolapse is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Less hydrated disc

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Posterior nucleus pulposus. Nucleus pulposus herniation results from a failure in the annulus fibrosis integrity, making the content of the nucleus to protrude into the neural canal, the intervertebral foramen (foraminal) or lateral to the foramen (extraforaminal). Nucleus pulposus protrusion is the less severe scenario of disc herniation, due to partial rupture of the annulus fibrosis, when the annulus structure becomes completely disrupted, the nucleus content may extrude outside the disc space and in some cases a fragment of nucleus pulposus may migrate ( sequestration ).
  • • Option B. Posterior nucleus pulposus.
  • • Option C. Weak ligamentum flavum . On morphology, there has been no evidence that ligamentum flavum contributes to the development of prolapse intervertebral disc disease.
  • • Option C. Weak ligamentum flavum
  • • Option D. More degenerative forces . The loss of proteoglycan in degenerated discs has a major effect on the disc's load-bearing behaviour. With loss of proteoglycan, the osmotic pressure of the disc falls and the disc is less able to maintain hydration under load. When loaded, they lose height and fluid more rapidly, and the discs tend to bulge. Due to loss of proteoglycan and matrix disorganization, degenerated discs no longer behave hydrostatically under load. Loading thus leads to inappropriate stress along the end-plate or in the annulus. Such changes in disc behaviour may affect function of other spinal structures and predispose them to injury. For instance, due to rapid loss of disc height under load in degenerated discs, apophyseal joints adjacent to the discs may be subject to abnormal loads and eventually develop osteoarthritic changes. Loss of disc height can also reduce the tensional forces on the ligamentum flavum and hence, may cause remodeling and thickening. With consequent loss of elasticity, the ligament tends to bulge into the spinal canal, leading to spinal stenosis, which is seen most commonly in elderly patients.
  • • Option D. More degenerative forces
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In the lumbar spine, the most common factor that leads to disc prolapse is the inadequate or less hydration of the disc due to ageing.
  • • In the lumbar spine, the most common factor that leads to disc prolapse is the inadequate or less hydration of the disc due to ageing.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presented with acute onset of low backache radiating to the right lower limb. Examination revealed SLRT < 40 degrees on the right side, weakness of extensor hallucis longus on the right side, sensory loss in the first web space of the right foot and brisk knee jerk. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prolapsed intervertebral disc L4-L5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Spondylolysis L5-S1. Spondylolysis pain feels like a dull ache pain across the low back area. There is soreness and stiffness in the buttocks and back of the thigh. Bending backward or performing twisting movements increases spondylolysis pain in the low back.
  • • Option B. Spondylolysis L5-S1.
  • • Option C. Lumbar canal stenosis . Classically, LSS presents with axial low back pain, radiculopathy, or neurological claudication aggravated by ambulation and lumbar extension. Neurogenic claudication is an important feature of LSS. Symptoms are typically bilateral but usually asymmetric. Numbness and tingling typically involve the entire leg. Patients may also report walking upstairs being easier than downstairs. The "shopping cart sign” has also been described, wherein forward flexion relieves back pain. The "simian stance," characterized by walking with the trunk and knees slightly flexed, may be observed.
  • • Option C. Lumbar canal stenosis
  • • Option D. Spondylolisthesis L4-L5 . Spondylolisthesis doesn’t usually have any symptoms. It is commonly seen on X-rays and CT scans as an ‘incidental’ finding. Back pain is the most common symptom that is typically worse with activities such as bending and lifting, and often eases when lying down. As the spine attempts to stabilise the unstable segment, the facet joints enlarge and place pressure on the nerve root causing lumbar spinal stenosis and lateral recess stenosis. As there is forward slippage of one bone on the other, there is also narrowing of the intervertebral foramen (foraminal stenosis). Severe nerve compression can therefore occur with pain, numbness and weakness in the legs. Sometimes loss of control of the bladder and/or bowels can occur due to pressure on the nerves going to these structures.
  • • Option D. Spondylolisthesis L4-L5
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The prolapsed intervertebral disc at L5-S1 may present with symptoms of low back pain radiating to the limb. The SLR test is positive on the affected side, with weakening of the EHL muscle strength, sensory loss on the first web space of the affected side foot and brisk knee jerk.

questions.text: Gradual, painful limitation of shoulder movements in an elderly suggest that the most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Periarthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis . Pain in the shoulder joint is the major sign of arthritis. It can be present in the front, side or back of the shoulder. Some people may have pain even at rest or during any activity. It can be present with or without shoulder stiffness. Often the pain is worse with lifting, carrying heavy objects or after exercising. The pain can often radiate into the arm or, if severe, can radiate down to the elbow and wrist. Stiffness of the joint is another sign of progression of shoulder arthritis. There may be loss of range of motion in the shoulder. Crepitus may be felt which may or may not be painful. Sometimes the shoulder may “lock up.”
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis
  • • Pain in the shoulder joint
  • • Stiffness of the joint
  • • Crepitus
  • • Option C. Myositis ossificans . Heterotrophic ossification in shoulder is a rare entity. It may occur following a trauma to the shoulder. The patient may present with pain, tenderness, swelling and decreased range of motion within few days of the injury. There may be a palpable soft tissue mass in the shoulder. The pain and the size of the mass decreases with time. There is also restricted shoulder motion.
  • • Option C. Myositis ossificans
  • • Option D. Fracture-dislocation . The fracture-dislocation presents with pain, swelling and bruising around the affected area. The patient is unable to move the shoulder. There is a crepitus on movement of the shoulder. There is also a presentation of a deformity in the shoulder that does not look right.
  • • Option D. Fracture-dislocation
  • • Educational objective:

  • • Gradual, painful limitation of the shoulder movements in an elderly patient suggests that there is a presentation of frozen shoulder or periarthritis of the shoulder.

questions.text: About Kienbock Osteonecrosis, all are true except: Tenderness over base of 5th metatarsal is present Pain is more on wrist flexion than wrist extension Is the osteochondritis of lunate Is associated with positive ulnar variance More common in elderly
